About: The Aldo Leopold Foundation invites volunteers to help care for the historic Leopold Shack and surrounding lands, preserving natural habitats and honoring Aldo Leopold’s legacy. Volunteers can participate in land stewardship, educational programs, and community outreach to promote the land ethic—a philosophy of respectful, ethical connection with nature. By joining, you’ll help inspire conservation leadership and contribute to protecting ecosystems for future generations.

We are looking for volunteers to provide additional programming at Buckhorn State Park this summer to supplement friends group programs. Hikes, drop-in programs, kayaking, formal programs at the amphitheater, and foraging for fall mushrooms.

Organization: Carpenter St. Croix Valley Nature Center
About: Calling all bat nerds! We are seeking help from knowledgeable volunteers who love bats to help with our 2023 Bioblitz. Weather it is a full bat program or bat hike, we are excited to education our community on the wonders of the night.
Volunteers will assist in digging holes, planting trees and securing tree tubes around the new seedlings.

A pumpkin based activity that connects kids 6-13 to the nature and elements around them. Also focusing on using every element of the pumpkin in fun and creative ways and how to connect this to other foods/activities in life.

Organization: City of Neenah - Park and Recreation Dept
About: As the development of Arrowhead Park begins with near shore and shoreline habitat restorations and also a future prairie restoration we want to monitor the impacts of these habitat restorations. Impacts monitored will include fish, aquatic bugs, birds, turtles, bees, butterflies and plants. Arrowhead is located on the south shores of Little Lake Butte des Morts, Neenah and is a migratory route for birds.
Looking for folks interested in leading hikes or manning the nature cabin (training will be provided) by the park naturalist. Bat ambassadors also invited to participate in night hikes.

Organization: Dane County Land and Water Resources Dept.
About: The Dane County LWRD is seeking help from Master Naturalists to get trained on presenting rainfall simulators (either tabletop or trailered version) to supplement the staff capacity of our office. The simulator is very interactive and shows how different land use types (turf grass, prairie, agriculture, etc.) perform during a rainfall event in terms of infiltration and potential erosion. This could be a great opportunity for someone who wants to periodically do tabling events and educate the public on the importance of deep rooted plants and limiting erosion.

Driftless Area Land Conservancy is developing a 50-mile hiking trail, called the Driftless Trail, in northeastern Iowa County. This will serve as a resource for recreation, education, and land conservation for seven rural communities and the Madison area. Volunteers are needed to construct new trail tread and maintain existing trail segments.

Lead a short sunset hike highlighting nocturnal animals, sounds, and natural life on the grounds of Durwards Glen in the beautiful Baraboo Bluffs. The group will be adult day camp participants and events are centered around wellness and appreciation of nature.
Working on a small nature trail in the village of Eagle: helping with management of prairie, woods and pond areas, including removal of invasives, planting projects, children's activities.

A peaceful 26-acre tract of prairie west of Madison at Folklore Village Farm (www.folklorevillagefarm.org) was in danger of losing its CRP certification and needs your help. Volunteers have worked hard the past 9 months to catch up with years of neglect, so it's looking much better, but needs a big July push against summer invasives.
Looking for some help with our bird city designation.

At Fox-Wolf, we believe healthy waters build vibrant communities. Working hand-in-hand with local partners, businesses, and residents, we’re dedicated to protecting and revitalizing the Fox-Wolf Watershed—ensuring clean, thriving waterways for everyone who call this amazing place home. https://fwwa.org/get-involved/volunteer/

Organization: Friends of Doyne Park in Milwaukee
About: Calling all Volunteers! Weed Out Gathering at Doyne Park from 10am-1pm September 29th!!!! Time to address those nasty Buckthorns and pull them out with PullerBears!

Full moon hike guide! Looking for a naturalist who can lead a group of young adults on a moonlight hike and share cool facts about critters at night! We will walk through an oak savanna and a restored prairie. If you don't mind being the groups "Ooo, what was that sound?" expert and think hiking in the dark is an adventure please join us!
Prairie Seed Collection. Sign up here: https://secure.lglforms.com/form_engine/s/GEwmqTOp80eAdnqpixAqlg

Friends of the Monarch Trail seeks volunteers to help maintain extensive pollinator friendly grounds and trails in Wauwatosa; to provide assistance at special events such as our annual plant sale; assist with monarch count in the Fall; and provide information and education at our annual celebration. If you have a passion for helping us continue to provide an established stopping point for these beautiful butterflies during their migration, we would love to have you join us in this important endeavor. If you are interested, please contact Linda Sheridan at lsheridan726@gmail.com

Girl Scouts of Wisconsin is hosting their Girl Scout Day Camp, which is completely volunteer run and is seeking naturalists to run one or more programs of their choosing for girls ages 5-12 who are divided into groups of 8-14 girls by age. Our camp does have a small budget for supplies but the volunteer would need to register with Girl Scouts as a volunteer ($25) which covers their insurance and background check (must be through Girl Scouts even if you have a current background check). Meals are included for volunteers and volunteers are encouraged to participate in other programming when not running their own program (try your hand at archery, crafts, camp skills etc). Please contact Jessica Martin for more information, muschj99@yahoo.com
We are looking for master naturalists who are interested in presenting educational programs this spring/summer/fall for children, adults and families at the nature center.
Serve as a community partner to help create and sustain youth nature and place-based programs at La Crosse County Library
Lac Lawrann Conservancy is looking for help with land stewardship and educational programs (field trips, summer camp, snow shoe events, girl and boy scout events).

We are recruiting volunteers and community scientists to help us with the Neighborhood Habitat Improvement Project, which aims to improve residential areas for birds, pollinators, and water quality. 

Birdscape Botanist volunteers will learn native and nonnative plant species, and how to use standard forestry tools while surveying a 5-meter site surrounding one of our breeding bird boxes to determine if clutch size and survival rates are better in areas with more dense native woody vegetation.

Nesting Navigator volunteers help The Observatory monitor breeding bird activity at over 100 constructed bird boxes throughout Port Washington, WI once to twice a week.

Climate Catalysts volunteers will help in our newest initiative which aims to produce biochar from woody invasive species slash generated from various partners' habitat restoration projects. When paired with tree planting Biochar can sequester carbon, retain and slow release water to trees, and filtrate and absorb pollutants, including nutrients. Through these properties, it is a powerful tool to promote resiliency of trees to future climate extremes, to filter pollutants (especially nutrients), to reduce air pollution from woody debris burning, and to address climate change. Work would include gathering and preparing woody debris for kilns, assisting kiln tenders with loading, and testing methods to "charge" biochar with nutrients by soaking the char in overly nutrient-rich local waterways prior to using in planting.

Organization: Lake Superior National Estuarine Research Reserve
About:
We are recruiting volunteers and community scientists to help us with the Neighborhood Habitat Improvement Project, which aims to improve residential areas for birds, pollinators, and water quality. 

Birdscape Botanist volunteers will learn native and nonnative plant species, and how to use standard forestry tools while surveying a 5-meter site surrounding one of our breeding bird boxes to determine if clutch size and survival rates are better in areas with more dense native woody vegetation.

Nesting Navigator volunteers help The Observatory monitor breeding bird activity at over 100 constructed bird boxes throughout Port Washington, WI once to twice a week.

Climate Catalysts volunteers will help in our newest initiative which aims to produce biochar from woody invasive species slash generated from various partners' habitat restoration projects. When paired with tree planting Biochar can sequester carbon, retain and slow release water to trees, and filtrate and absorb pollutants, including nutrients. Through these properties, it is a powerful tool to promote resiliency of trees to future climate extremes, to filter pollutants (especially nutrients), to reduce air pollution from woody debris burning, and to address climate change. Work would include gathering and preparing woody debris for kilns, assisting kiln tenders with loading, and testing methods to "charge" biochar with nutrients by soaking the char in overly nutrient-rich local waterways prior to using in planting.
Present an informational program to patrons/the public

We are looking for volunteer birders to lead Saturday Morning Bird Walks at Maywood Environmental Park. Enthusiastic Maywood birders meet at 7:30am to identify resident and migrating birds at Maywood. This is a casual program and everyone looks for birds together, so while birding skills are a plus, you certainly don’t need to be an expert. Rather, the leader is responsible for greeting people as they arrive, keeping the group together, and ensuring that everyone has fun!

Restoration Rangers is a volunteer program where volunteers assist MNP staff on a variety of land restoration work (invasive species removal, seed collection, native plant planting, monitoring, and mulching trails).

The Milwaukee Public Museum has partnered with the Aldo Leopold Foundation in Baraboo to host a Bioblitz on June 27-28, 2025. We are looking for surveyors to join us and help inventory species on the property. If you can put a name on it, we want to know about it! The event starts at 3 pm on the 27th (Friday) and runs till 3 pm on Saturday. You are welcome to join us for as much or as little of that time as you want, and can come and go as needed. Food & a t-shirt are provided. If you would like to survey, you can sign up here: https://forms.office.com/r/7rq2yTgAaY And if you have questions, please email Julia at colby@mpm.edu. The event is free and open to the public on Saturday, June 28th from 10-3; stop by and see what’s going on- and at 3pm we’ll report out about what we found!

The park is looking for a Master Naturalist to help with an interpretive program or two on a Friday or Saturday night about owls or other subjects. Contact the park naturalist with questions or to share your interest. Lexi Leonard, alexis.leonard@wisconsin.gov.

Organization: Monona Grove Liberal Arts Charter for the 21st Century (MG21) -- Middle Campus
About:
As one of the Middle Campus (grades 6-8) teachers at MG21, I am planning for our upcoming "Wilderness Week" out in the Cottage Grove School Forest. We've been building our Outdoor Program for the past two years, and will be bringing the kids out to the woods for the third iteration of "Wilderness Week" in March this year. 

One of the areas that we've been doing some learning in lately is managing our forest more sustainably - including invasive species identification and management. Right now, we are looking for expert collaborators who would be interested in joining us out at the forest as a guest speaker/teacher, particularly on this topic.

Organization: Newport State Park, WI Department of Natural Resources
About: Looking for someone who loves astronomy, star gazing, dark night skies and all things celestial who is willing to enthusiastically share their knowledge at Wisconsin's only dark sky park.

Organization: Northern Highland American Legion State Forest
About: We are looking for volunteers to conduct a presentation at our Nature Center. The audiance is normally a mix of ages, would prefer the program to deal with nature but open to any other ideas.

Organization: Restoring Lands: A Wisconsin Land Trust (formerly OWLT & RRF)
About:
Restoring Lands offers a weekly Land Stewardship volunteer program with volunteer workdays in Ozaukee, Washington, or Milwaukee counties. Removing invasive species, planting trees, and other projects. 
Restoring Lands is also bringing back our Community Science wildlife monitoring program, including amphibian funnel trapping, egg mass surveys, snake board monitoring, or independently monitoring wildlife on our preserves through eBird or iNaturalist.

I am looking for people who would be interested in doing roaming style presentations in the Gardens on a variety of topics. This would be a drop-in style presentation combined with visitors' general admission ticket to the Garden. Presentations would last about an hour. I already have presenters booked for Monarch Migration, Medieval Gardening, Wild Edible and Poisonous Plants and Fascinating Moths and Butterflies. Thank you for your consideration.

Looking for adult volunteers to canoe campers around our pond for summer camp. The Boys & Girls club summer camp joins Schlitz Audubon every summer for a fun, wild week of nature. We are looking for volunteers to canoe kids around our "Mystery Lake." Volunteers who are good with kids, canoes, and pond creature identification is requested.

The Bird Collision Corps is a Madison, WI-based citizen science project that works with volunteers who help study where bird collisions are happening in the Madison area. We have about 1/3 of our volunteer slots still open, in locations like UW-Madison, Madison College, Warner Park, and more. Volunteers document where birds hit windows and we work with site owners to treat their windows to minimize bird deaths. This program is making a difference for bird conservation in the area!

Come join one of the local The Prairie Enthusiasts chapters for a work day! Opportunities to work and learn include prescribed burning, invasive species removal, plant identification, seed collection, prairie plant ecology, and more. Tools and instruction are provided. Volunteer opportunities are chapter dependent, and are typically communicated via the listserv once you sign up. You can also contact the chair of your local chapter to obtain more information, or visit the events page on the website. https://theprairieenthusiasts.org/about-us/our-chapters/find-your-chapter/

Come support summer camp as an adult chaperone! Spend 4 days, 3 nights along the Wisconsin River as we create a safe and inclusive environment for all kids. Activities include hiking, canoeing, water ecology and more.
staff a table (with me - Chris Young) at UWM's Darwin Day to describe the Wisconsin Master Naturalist program for a public, drop-in audience

The intention of this outreach is for 1-2 Master Naturalist volunteers to help with coverage at the front desk of the NGLVC. Volunteers would be expected to help with short lunch shift coverages for our staff (2-3 times per month, both weekday and Saturdays possible), as well as the *occasional 1/2 day back up when staff experience illness/take vacation etc. The Volunteer(s) would also be expected to help with outdoor education and interpretation, serving as help for field trip groups, special events, and would also be encouraged to develop and run their own interpretive programs or events. There may also be opportunity for hands on volunteer service in the field (such as trail work, gardening, invasive species removal etc.) with both Forest Service and other partners such as the USFWS.

Organization: US Forest Service (Northern Great Lakes Visitor Center)
About: The Chequamegon-Nicolet National Forest is seeking out two Volunteers to work part time at the David R. Obey Northern Great Lakes Visitor Center (NGLVC). Occasional work may include working with the following partners: U.S. Forest Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, National Park Service, Wisconsin Historical Society, University of Wisconsin-Madison Division of Extension, and the Friends of the Center Alliance, Ltd. Volunteers will be expected to assist Forest Service and partner staff in planning and leading a variety of interpretive and educational programs on topics such as the Great Lakes, Ecology, and Cultural/Regional history, etc. Volunteers will also help to staff our front desk and provide quality visitor center services such as maintaining the front desk, greeting visitors and acquainting them with the Center’s programs and facilities, providing information about events, programs and recreational opportunities in the community, answering questions, providing guides, maps and regional information. In addition, volunteers will also have the opportunity to participate in a variety of natural resources-based projects such as trail maintenance/rehabilitation, water quality testing, native planting, invasive species control, and more. Please reach out to Amanda Koval and Lauren Romstad for more information: Amanda.koval@usda.gov, Lauren.romstad@usda.gov

Do you like being outside? Do you have a passion for protecting our shared natural resources? With a commitment of only a few hours per month, you can become a volunteer stream monitor with Water Action Volunteers (WAV).
Join a network of over 500 citizen scientist volunteers across the state
Have fun outside and connect with the natural world
Learn about water quality and aquatic life in your local stream
Collect valuable scientific data to inform stream management decisions

Volunteering with us is a great opportunity for individuals and groups to enjoy the outdoors while giving back to the community. Project needs vary depending on the time of year and on current projects going on in the Park System. Find volunteer opportunities here. If you would like to start the process to become a volunteer with Waukesha County Parks and Land Use as a teaching naturalist at Retzer, water monitor, citizen scientist, or as a land steward please visit this website.

The Waukesha Public Library has some planting beds on both sides of the front entrance that desperately need some attention. Our maintenance department has cleaned out the beds and they are ready for a refresh. We are open to your suggestions, and we have staff willing to help! (To qualify for Master Naturalist hours, the planters or beds need to be a pollinator garden, native garden, or rain garden. Planters just for beautification, while valuable, would be most suited for Master Gardeners.)
Raptor Program

Calling all anglers! Are you interested in teaching a new generation of fisherpeople? Join us at Beckman Mill Park in Beloit as we teach first and second grade students about fish adaptations and habitat requirements, and (of course) we will get our hands on some fish.

Come spend a day at Whitefish Dunes State Park for one of our public programs. Our programs are drop in style and usually run from 10-3pm (with flexibility). We will usually hold these programs on the beach or near our nature center. The majority of our audience is looking to go to the beach so this is a great opportunity to educate individuals who may have less knowledge of the Natural Resources! Our Naturalist is looking for experts to collaborate on the following programs:

Pollinators (Bumble Bee Brigade)
Bat Program (Calling all Bat Ambassadors!)
Beach Safety (We have bad rip currents and lots of swimmers at our beach!)
Greet visitors in Education Center in absence of staff naturalist. Assist with large education groups. Supervise fish games and activities at Spring and Fall open house events.
Raptor Program

This is an opportunity to lead a Natural Resources Foundation Field trip on Meadow Valley Wildlife Area alongside DNR's bureau of Wildlife Managment educational staff. This opportunity is meant to highlight the recreational opportunities available on these properties such as botanizing, birding, wildlife viewing, foraging, paddling, and hiking. There is ample opportunity for this field trip to be tailored to the leader's naturalist background knowledge. Please reach out and we can discuss details and dates!

Help us care for some of our state's most pristine public lands, State Natural Areas (SNA). Encourage native plants and animals to thrive by cutting brush, controlling invasive species, collecting seeds, monitoring rare species and preparing fire breaks. Show up for a day or become a steward responsible for all volunteer activities at a SNA. Any level of participation is encouraged and no experience is necessary to start volunteering. Learn more at the DNR website.

If you like to spend time in the outdoors, interact with and help other outdoor enthusiasts, and you care about protecting our natural resources, then the Wisconsin State Park System needs you! Volunteers are needed at state parks, forests, recreation areas, trails and scenic waters across the state.Volunteers may donate their time for what their schedule allows. Whether you're volunteering for a few hours at a property workday, or for a couple of weeks as a campground host, your service makes a world of difference. Check out the website for a current list of volunteer opportunities around the state with the Wisconsin State Park System.
